Custom slash commands work at two levels:
1. **Global**: `/home/joaod/.claude/commands/` (works in all projects)
2. **Project**: `./.claude/commands/` (works only in current project)

Your global commands should be working. Let me check if there's a specific command you're trying to use:

    27‚Üí### Arguments Parsing

    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí* The company name, either from the person's title or from the message body
    32‚Üí* The recruiting company name (for contract positions), either from the person's title or from the message body
    33‚Üí* The recruiter's name

    35‚Üí* The date and time of the message, if it is only a day of the week or a hours ago calculate the datetime it was received.
    36‚Üí  Note that it is always presented in the -07:00 timezone, unless explicitly stated otherwise.
    37‚Üí* Subject of the message (if available)
    38‚Üí* The message body
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí#### Input format
    41‚Üí
    42‚ÜíBelow are texts written in mixed of regex and text., like a regex using python's f-string format for variables.
    43‚ÜíIf multiple messages arrived, they are separated by a triple dash `\n---\n`.
    44‚ÜíIt comes in one of the following formats:
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí##### Format 1 - LinkedIn
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí* Note that, sometimes, the person includes their company in their title, like "Talent Partner@ Amazon Robotics".
    49‚Üí* In that case, you should extract the company name from the title.
    50‚Üí* Gender pronouns are optional
    51‚Üí* "\nVerified recruiter" is optional
    52‚Üí* ", #HIRING" is optional
    53‚Üí* "\nüëè\nüëç\nüòä\n+" is optional
    54‚Üí* "{{subject}}\n" is optional
    55‚Üí* "\n{2,}{{attachment_filename}}\n\n{{attachment_size}}\n\nDownload" is optional
    56‚Üí* You should infer the desired variables from the text.
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí```text
    59‚Üí{{full_name}}(\n\({{gender_pronouns}}\))?\n{{degree_connection}} degree connection\n¬∑ {{degree_connection}}\n{{person_title}}\n(\nVerified recruiter)?\n{{day_of_week_or_date}}\n{{full_name}} sent the following messages at {{time}}\nView {{first_name}}‚Äôs profile{{full_name}}(, #HIRING)?\n{{full_name}}( \({{gender_pronouns}}\))?  {{time}}(\nüëè\nüëç\nüòä\n+)?\n+({{subject}}\n)?{{message_body}}(\n{2,}{{attachment_filename}}\n\n{{attachment_size}}\n\nDownload)?

file.content:
---
description: Create a new history and input file in the @job-hunting/history and @job-hunting/input directories.
argument-hint: Raw text copy-pasted from either email or linkedin
allowed-tools: Task, Read, TodoWrite, Write, LS, Grep, Glob, Edit
---

## Context

Arguments: $ARGUMENTS
Arguments is a raw text copy-pasted from either email or linkedin

## Task

Your task is to create 2 files:

* A new history file in the @job-hunting/history directory.
* A new input file in the @job-hunting/input directory.

### Steps

1. Parse the arguments to extract the desired information
2. analyze the arguments to determine the best template to use
3. analyze the arguments to extract non-obvious information, like the datetime of the message and company name
4. Create the history file
5. Create the input file

### Arguments Parsing

You should parse the arguments to extract the following information:

* The company name, either from the person's title or from the message body

Below are texts written in mixed of regex and text., like a regex using python's f-string format for variables.
If multiple messages arrived, they are separated by a triple dash `\n---\n`.
It comes in one of the following formats:

* "\nVerified recruiter" is optional

input.content:
context:
  - Do not forget to mention that I require H1B Visa Sponsorship for any new position.
platform: email
process_status: application response
conversation_history:
  - timestamp: 2025-09-17T08:00:00-07:00 Tuesday
    from: Jake Kartes <jakekartes@anthropic.com>
    subject: Anthropic Automated Interview Invitation - Jo√£o Marco Maciel da Silva | Senior Software Engineer, Search
    body: |
      Hi Jo√£o Marco,

      Thank you for your application to Anthropic!

      We thought your application was quite promising, and as a next step, we'd like to invite you to do an automated technical screen through the CodeSignal platform. You should receive an invite from CodeSignal shortly; if you don't see it in your inbox today, please let us know. Please note that the link expires in one month, but we strongly encourage you to complete the assessment within 2 weeks if at all possible.

      The CodeSignal platform will give you a choice of coding language, but we ask that you take the test in any of these languages: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Go, Ruby, Java, and C++. We will not consider results submitted in other languages. The test time limit is 90 minutes. If you choose to complete the test in Java, the Java code will be wrapped into a larger class wrapper.

      The CodeSignal screen is intended to test your ability to quickly and correctly write and refactor working code. You will not be evaluated on code quality. You'll be asked to implement a simple coding project from a spec, broken into four levels. Your code will need to pass all tests in a given level to move forward to the next level. For many candidates, the later levels take more time to complete than the earlier ones. You should prioritize progressing through all four levels quickly, and getting as many tests as possible to pass if you are not able to complete a level.

      The project will be a toy simulation of an app that won't require anything except the standard library of your chosen programming language. Note there's no framework/UI or anything similar ‚Äî basically, it's like the core business logic of an app, but nothing else. It won't test detailed knowledge of algorithms, compute systems, or machine learning.

      Please do your work only within the CodeSignal platform, and do not use an external IDE or editor. You are not allowed to use Github Copilot or other LLMs, or copy code that solves the problem from a web resource or book. This will result in a failing score. You may consult web resources or books for specific technical questions, for example, to look up language documentation.

      Let me know if you have any questions!

      Best,
      Jake

platform: email
process_status: interview scheduling
conversation_history:
  - timestamp: 2025-09-17T08:00:00-07:00 Tuesday
    from: Jake Kartes <jakekartes@anthropic.com>
    subject: Anthropic Automated Interview Invitation - Jo√£o Marco Maciel da Silva | Senior Software Engineer, Search
    body: |
      Hi Jo√£o Marco,

      Thank you for your application to Anthropic!

      We thought your application was quite promising, and as a next step, we'd like to invite you to do an automated technical screen through the CodeSignal platform. You should receive an invite from CodeSignal shortly; if you don't see it in your inbox today, please let us know. Please note that the link expires in one month, but we strongly encourage you to complete the assessment within 2 weeks if at all possible.

      The CodeSignal platform will give you a choice of coding language, but we ask that you take the test in any of these languages: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Go, Ruby, Java, and C++. We will not consider results submitted in other languages. The test time limit is 90 minutes. If you choose to complete the test in Java, the Java code will be wrapped into a larger class wrapper.

      The CodeSignal screen is intended to test your ability to quickly and correctly write and refactor working code. You will not be evaluated on code quality. You'll be asked to implement a simple coding project from a spec, broken into four levels. Your code will need to pass all tests in a given level to move forward to the next level. For many candidates, the later levels take more time to complete than the earlier ones. You should prioritize progressing through all four levels quickly, and getting as many tests as possible to pass if you are not able to complete a level.

      The project will be a toy simulation of an app that won't require anything except the standard library of your chosen programming language. Note there's no framework/UI or anything similar ‚Äî basically, it's like the core business logic of an app, but nothing else. It won't test detailed knowledge of algorithms, compute systems, or machine learning.

      Please do your work only within the CodeSignal platform, and do not use an external IDE or editor. You are not allowed to use Github Copilot or other LLMs, or copy code that solves the problem from a web resource or book. This will result in a failing score. You may consult web resources or books for specific technical questions, for example, to look up language documentation.

      Let me know if you have any questions!

      Best,
      Jake
